title: BridgeHand2Vec Bridge Hand Representation
authors: Anna Sztyber-Betley, Filip Kołodziej, Jan Betley, Piotr Duszak
keyAssumptions: Hand evaluation can't be reduced to simple additive metrics
keyHypotheses: Neural network embeddings can capture hand strength relationships
strengths: SOTA results on DDBP2, interpretable vector space
weaknesses: Limited to trick prediction, not full bridge evaluation
citation: Sztyber-Betley, A. et al. (2023). BridgeHand2Vec Bridge Hand Representation. arXiv:2310.06624
notes: First successful neural embedding approach for bridge hands

title: Hand Strength Evaluation in Bridge Games with the Genetic Algorithm
authors: Jing-Ping Jan, Kuo-Si Huang, Chang-Biau Yang
keyHypotheses: Genetic algorithm can optimize hand evaluation parameters
citation: Jan, J.P., Huang, K.S., Yang, C.B. (2023). Hand Strength Evaluation in Bridge Games with the Genetic Algorithm
notes: First systematic optimization of traditional point count parameters

title: Competitive Bridge Bidding with Deep Neural Networks
authors: Jiang Rong, Tao Qin, Bo An
keyAssumptions: Rule-based systems cannot cover all bidding situations
keyHypotheses: Dual neural networks can handle imperfect information bidding
strengths: First deep learning bidding system, outperforms rule-based programs
weaknesses: Still requires domain knowledge in representation design
citation: Rong, J., Qin, T., An, B. (2019). Competitive Bridge Bidding with Deep Neural Networks. AAMAS
notes: Breakthrough in applying deep learning to bridge bidding

title: Finding Optimal Strategies for Imperfect Information Games
authors: Ian Frank, David Basin, Hitoshi Matsubara
keyAssumptions: Monte Carlo sampling provides adequate approximation for imperfect information
keyHypotheses: Vector minimax and payoff-reduction can outperform Monte Carlo
strengths: First to identify strategy fusion and non-locality problems
citation: Frank, I., Basin, D., Matsubara, H. (1998). Finding Optimal Strategies for Imperfect Information Games. AAAI
notes: Foundational work identifying fundamental PIMC problems

title: GIB: Imperfect Information in a Computationally Challenging Game
keyAssumptions: Perfect Information Monte Carlo adequate for bridge cardplay
keyHypotheses: Multiple technical advances can overcome PIMC limitations
weaknesses: Strategy fusion and non-locality problems remain
citation: Ginsberg, M. (2001). GIB: Imperfect Information in a Computationally Challenging Game. JAIR
notes: Foundation for modern bridge AI, used in commercial GIB program

title: The αμ Search Algorithm for the Game of Bridge
keyAssumptions: Perfect information assumption for opponents while preserving incomplete info for player
keyHypotheses: Anytime heuristic search can address strategy fusion and non-locality
strengths: Addresses fundamental PIMC problems, anytime algorithm
citation: Cazenave, T., Ventos, V. (2019). The αμ Search Algorithm for the Game of Bridge. arXiv:1911.07960
notes: Novel search algorithm addressing PIMC limitations

title: Recursive Monte Carlo Search for Bridge Card Play
authors: Bruno Bouzy, Alexis Rimbaud, Veronique Ventos
keyAssumptions: Recursive Monte Carlo can outperform standard MC with more resources
keyHypotheses: Level N+1 RMC using Level N RMC as simulator improves performance
strengths: 0.5 trick improvement per distribution, eliminates DDS dependence
weaknesses: Exponential computation time increase per recursion level
citation: Bouzy, B., Rimbaud, A., Ventos, V. (2020). Recursive Monte Carlo Search for Bridge Card Play. IEEE CoG
notes: First successful recursive Monte Carlo application to bridge

title: Automatic Bridge Bidding Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Chih-Kuan Yeh, Cheng-Yu Hsieh, Hsuan-Tien Lin
keyAssumptions: Raw card data contains sufficient information for expert bidding
keyHypotheses: Deep Q-learning can learn bidding from scratch without domain knowledge
strengths: Learns without human-designed systems, outperforms champion programs
weaknesses: Requires significant computational resources for training
citation: Yeh, C.K., Hsieh, C.Y., Lin, H.T. (2024). Automatic Bridge Bidding Using Deep Reinforcement Learning. IEEE ToG
notes: First system to learn expert bidding purely from raw data

title: A Simple, Solid, and Reproducible Baseline for Bridge Bidding AI
authors: Haruka Kita, Sotetsu Koyamada, Yotaro Yamaguchi, Shin Ishii
keyAssumptions: Simple combination of existing methods can outperform complex approaches
keyHypotheses: Proper baseline is more important than algorithmic novelty
weaknesses: Limited novelty, relies on existing techniques
citation: Kita, H. et al. (2024). A Simple, Solid, and Reproducible Baseline for Bridge Bidding AI. IEEE CoG
notes: Demonstrates importance of solid baselines in bridge AI research

title: Information Set Monte Carlo Tree Search
authors: Peter Cowling, Edward Powley, Daniel Whitehouse
journal: IEEE Transactions on Computational Intelligence and AI in Games
keyAssumptions: Searching information sets more effective than game states for imperfect information
keyHypotheses: ISMCTS can handle different sources of hidden information and uncertainty
strengths: Successfully applied to multiple card games, commercial success
citation: Cowling, P., Powley, E., Whitehouse, D. (2012). Information Set Monte Carlo Tree Search. IEEE TCIAIG
notes: Theoretical foundation for information set search in imperfect information games

title: Advances in computer bridge: techniques for a partial-information, communication-based game
keyAssumptions: Both inference and learning approaches needed for bridge AI advancement
keyHypotheses: Deep RL can learn bidding beyond rule-based systems
strengths: Comprehensive analysis of both bidding and cardplay
weaknesses: Academic work with limited practical implementation
citation: Bethe, P.M. (2021). Advances in computer bridge: techniques for a partial-information, communication-based game. NYU PhD Dissertation
notes: Thorough academic treatment of bridge as AI challenge

title: Learning Multi-agent Implicit Communication Through Actions: A Case Study in Contract Bridge
authors: Zheng Tian, Shihao Zou, Tim Warr, Lisheng Wu, Jun Wang
keyAssumptions: Actions serve dual purpose: exploitation and information communication
keyHypotheses: Policy-Belief-Iteration can learn implicit communication in imperfect information games
strengths: Novel approach to multi-agent communication, bridge as testbed
citation: Tian, Z. et al. (2018). Learning Multi-agent Implicit Communication Through Actions: A Case Study in Contract Bridge. arXiv:1810.04444
notes: Innovative approach to partnership cooperation in imperfect information settings

title: Learning a Double Dummy Bridge Solver
keyAssumptions: Machine learning can replace traditional double dummy solvers
keyHypotheses: Neural networks can predict trick-taking from card holdings
strengths: First systematic ML approach to double dummy solving
weaknesses: Only 35% accuracy on notrump, simple state representation
citation: Mernagh, M. (2016). Learning a Double Dummy Bridge Solver. Stanford CS229 Project
notes: Early attempt at ML-based double dummy solving, limited success

title: Perfect Information Monte Carlo with Postponing Reasoning
authors: Jérôme Arjonilla, Abdallah Saffidine, Tristan Cazenave
keyAssumptions: Postponing perfect information resolution reduces strategy fusion
keyHypotheses: Extended PIMC (EPIMC) can improve performance in high strategy fusion games
strengths: Addresses fundamental PIMC limitations, theoretical contributions
weaknesses: Introduces novel considerations about deferred resolution
citation: Arjonilla, J., Saffidine, A., Cazenave, T. (2024). Perfect Information Monte Carlo with Postponing Reasoning. IEEE CoG
notes: Latest advancement in addressing PIMC strategy fusion problems

title: The Synergy of Double Neural Networks for Bridge Bidding
keyAssumptions: Multiple neural networks can synergistically improve bridge performance
keyHypotheses: Dual network architecture outperforms individual components
weaknesses: Limited evaluation scope, unclear practical impact
citation: Yang, F. (2022). The Synergy of Double Neural Networks for Bridge Bidding. Mathematics, 10(17), 3187
notes: Explores systematic integration of multiple ML components
